Description: Terracotta amulet-mould, made of grey-brown micaceous Nile silt fabric; crudely shaped semi-circular back of mould; cut out motif in the shape of wedjat-eye in bulla form, with reeded suspension loop modelled in one piece with shape of amulet at the top; no visible remains of paste/glaze inside mould.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (noted in Petrie's plate)
Curator's comments: Petrie refers in his text listing the moulds to ' two for eye bullae' (1886, 37). Very similar to Petrie's drawing, but not the same, nor is it same as 1920.0417.6 Petrie's drawing has regularised the design. Possibly cut straight into mould with a point, and not impressed from a master.

In addition to glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids, the ‘Scarab Factory’ at Naukratis was also producing amulets (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming; see also Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Petrie listed a number of amulet-moulds including a similar type of this piece (Petrie 1886, 37, pl. XXXVIII, 16). Several similar moulds used to produced wedjat-eye in bulla form were discovered in Naukratis: BM 1920,0417.6, Oxford Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4572, Oxford Ashmolean Museum AN1888.216.10 and Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 11.45969. This specimen is particularly close to Oxford Ashmolean Museum AN1888.216.10. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 16) (almost identical cast)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OJ.06) (phase 2)
Condition: Good. Traces of pink matter round edge may =Plaster of Paris??
Acquisition date: 1880 (too early for Naukratis! Is this date a mistake?)
